ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: In this course, you'll receive elementary knowledge of C, MATLAB, and C++ (including an understanding of computer memory and how the languages interact with computer memory and the compiler). You'll also develop your problem solving abilities because every problem set is an application of the syntax and functions being taught for a given language.
Coding skills in C, C++, and Matlab

- Coding in C, C++, and Matlab.
- Basic coding style knowledge that isn't expressly necessary for the content of the course, but is important when you have less computer memory to work with or a larger program
- Basic applications of CS concepts such as numerical methods and physics modeling
Learned C, C++, and a little bit of matlab
C, MATLAB, and C++
I learned how to use C, C++, and MATLAB to solve problems and make graphics.
Intro coding skills as applicable to engineering problems.

I learned exactly what's in the course description. Most importantly, the continual exposure to solving different problems using C, C++ and Matlab helped me build my intuition. It was never easy for me, but towards the end of the course I felt I got better at coding for sure.

I came away from this course with a good understanding of C, C++, and MATLAB. These coding languages will be useful going forward in my major and also taught me how to think through solving coding problems, which will be applicable going forward.
Learned computer programming with basically no actual experience beforehand. Feel much more of a confident programmer, and excited to apply this information to future courses and jobs.
Learning how to code in C, C++ and Matlab
I learned C, C++, and MATLAB. I also learned problem solving skills!
Basic procedural and object-oriented programming skills through the languages of C, C++, and MATLAB. Focus on applications to various situations/algorithms in engineering and science.
Learned C, some Matlab, and C++. Improved my problem-solving skills
C, C++, and MATLAB, arrays, object-oriented programming

I was very new to programming coming into this course so I learned a ton from the fundamentals of programming and coding to the specifics of three programming languages: C, C++, and a bit of MatLab. My confidence as a programmer greatly increased and I have the tools to continue learning these languages on my own. The class was also a great exercise in problem solving.
Basic coding in engineering-based coding languages.
I learned a lot about how to code in C, C++, and matlab.
I learned basic programming and problem solving skills.
Lots of good coding
I learned how to code in C, MATLAB, C++. I learned how to solve engineering problems using my coding skills.
C, C++, some Matlab.
I learned some C, MATLAB, and C++ in this class. I also learned several useful methods/tips for organizing my work and checking if certain procedures worked which can be applicable in future work.
Learned a good amount about programming that will be useful in future engineering courses.

I learned the basics of C and C++ and Matlab, in addition to how to solve engineering and scientific problems through computer science. I learned how to write cleaner code and avoid common mistakes, and how set up a problem-solving approach in general.
I learned how to use MATLAB, C, and C++.
strong foundation in C and C++ programming and good coding practices
Amazing class with a really excellent professor
Great course!! C and Matlab skills

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: The lectures are great and clearly communicate concepts. I don't think I ever felt confused after a lecture and always had a clear understanding of the concepts as they were being taught. I like that Dr. Bennett types up thorough lecture notes which really help when you want to go back and review something. The problem sets are also really interesting applications of the programming languages that you're taught. This class should be listed as one of the options for an introductory programming experience on the computer science major page because it's better than any of the other introductory courses at Yale except maybe CS50 (the quality of each class varies depending on what you're looking for). 

Weaknesses: There aren't really any weaknesses for this course. The exams are a bit of a time crunch but still doable. The grading on the problem sets can be a bit harsh (which is probably due to the fact that there are some overqualified people taking this course), and I think the rubrics should focus more on fundamentals in programming rather than subjective errors like "not having enough comments", but it's not really that big of a deal (just remember to double check that you've stayed consistent with the "good coding style" tips that Dr. Bennett puts in her lecture slides). My only real criticism of the course is that Qt has to be the worst IDE I've ever used (sorry if Qt holds sentimental value to anyone reading this). It's just not friendly with Macs and it's not visually appealing in my opinion). I think the course should simply cut the computer graphics component covered in C and C++ (which is the only reason why we really use Qt), lengthen the time spent on MATLAB to supplement this, and move the coverage of C and C++ to VS Code or GitHub Codespaces. I'm yet to meet somebody that uses C and C++ to implement graphics into code, so I don't think it's an integral component to the coverage of C and C++ in this course and moving to VS Code would make things so much easier in my opinion. If this is, in fact, your first introduction to programming, you probably won't notice that Qt is not that great, but if you've been spoiled with good-looking IDEs like me in the past, just be prepared. Despite this, it's still a great course, and if Dr. Bennett continues to use Qt, you'll live.

Strengths
- Teaches useful coding for engineering majors

Weaknesses 
- Moves very fast, can be difficult for those without prior knowledge

Strengths: 
- Plenty of office hours with TAs, peer tutors, and Dr. Bennett.
- Great lecture recordings and slides
- Lots of resources that can be accessed through Canvas like sample codes and other notes
Weaknesses: 
- There might have been too much focus on "good coding style" in assignments grading. While readability and memory efficiency are definitely important, in a "real-world" setting you might have someone else to look over your code for you and help you fix these errors (but our collaboration policy prohibits this), so taking off so many points for coding style on a code that already perfectly produces the specified output seems a bit unnecessary.
- Maybe spend a bit less time on sample codes in lecture, since we can easily look through those on our own.
Organization was great, I only wish office hours were in person, as the zoom hours result in lots of waiting around.
Very well structured, P-sets may be a little long.
Professor Bennett is the strength. She is an amazing professor. She expects a lot out of you but also gives you the all of the tools to get there.

Strengths: Very well organized, many opportunities for office hours/supplemental help, should you need it. 

Weaknesses: none that I can think of!
The course was well structured. Access to information was seamless. Dr. Bennett is great at communicating important information.

This course could be divided a bit better to give more time to learning MATLAB. I also found exams to be very difficult, as the timespan of the exam was too short to allow me to properly debug my code. I also found the requirements of problem sets to be a bit opaque, as I often lost a lot of points for arbitrary formatting that did not relate to my understanding of the problem and the correct output. However, this course does cover a lot of material and gives students a lot of practice with each coding language.
The class is taught very well. The lectures are great and the information is very detailed. Some times the grading is a bit infuriating, but nothing major.

Strengths: learning how to code

Weaknesses: Not as much interaction with material until working on Psets
It is extremely well taught by prof. Bennett. Thorough and helpful.
Prof. Bennett is a great professor but her lectures are a little hard to stay engaged with.
It was extremely well organized and put together. I think the problem sets were very reasonably difficult and very engaging. The lectures were also great. And there was so much support for students.

Strengths: Professor Bennett is an incredibly helpful and clear lecturer. She is obviously dedicated to seeing her students succeed and has so many resources available to help them, including drop-in help sessions, office hours, lecture and super clear instructions. She explained everything in a clear and straightforward manner and always provided examples, such that I was rarely (if ever) confused during the course. Problem sets are reasonable in terms of difficulty and amount of work. The only one that I spent a significant amount of time completing was the final problem set. The material is also super useful for future classes, jobs, etc. Weaknesses: sometimes the lectures were a bit dry. However, this is probably more the fault of the material than the class. Does not help that this course was offered at 9 AM.
This course is very well structured and provides a great introduction to C, MatLab, and C++. This is also a great introductory coding class in general.
Professor Bennett is fantastic. The course is super organized and the material is interesting.
The course was well-organized and had many avenues of support.

Strenghts: clear lectures and lots of phenomenal help sessions
Grading is very specific for PSETs and projects, but this seems to be because the directions are specific. This isn't a weakness, but it's a challenge to be aware of when taking the course.

Strengths - highly organized and well-written PSETS.
Weaknesses - a lot of points get docked for small syntactical errors.
No complaints about the class, except I sucked at the exams (although I probably could've prepared more for them).
The course had interesting and applicable content. The course could increase its provision of support for students.

This course is so well organised and Professor Bennett goes so far out of her way to tailor it to the needs of her students. I have never had an easier time getting help on assignments, receiving feedback, or getting the chance to speak to a professor. This course is so well structured it is insane.
Very good! Beth is awesomeeeeeeeeee
I think the course was perfect! There were office hours almost every day, with peer tutors, TAs, or the professor herself willing to answer any of our questions.
Very well structured
Very organized course but the exams were extremely stressful with the time limit.
There are no weaknesses. The progression of the course is very smooth, and I think the amount of content taught and the workload is well-balanced. It was a really good experience!
The psets were very useful in gaining a deeper understanding of the material. The pace of the class was also manageable.
Course was amazing! PSETS were interesting. Lectures were well-made.

Office hours well run (maybe have one or two in person options a week) 
GREAT PROF 
Well structured 
Lots of opportunities to cement understanding  
Work load is manageable
Great course, nothing to complain about

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. This course is a fantastically structured intro to CS class, especially for those going into engineering. While most people are going to take this because it's required for their major (myself included), I would recommend it to anyone looking for a good intro to CS class that isn't CS 50. Beth is a fantastic professor; she literally has the most clearly structured canvas page I have ever seen. She provides so many resources to students for use. In terms of lectures, she always posts the lecture slides, lectures are recorded, edited, and posted to Canvas, and you can even live stream into the lecture if you don't want to walk to class. There are also sample codes posted which are invaluable for psets, and she has an abundance of office hours/drop in help sessions with TAs. If you start psets at least a few days before the deadline, they're very manageable. Before each midterm, a full practice exam is posted with the same structure as the actual exam, and she uses one full lecture as a review session. Some people say that the lectures are slightly dry, but I didn't really find that to be the case. I thought all the material was well explained and interesting enough on its own, perhaps not more than average but sufficient enough for me to stay engaged. Overall, this is a beautifully organized class that I would recommend to anyone who doesn't have coding experience and/or needs it for their major.

Definitely, although, I would recommend you have some coding experience in any language of choice just so that your problem-solving skills are well developed before you enter this course. In all honesty, if they cut the computer graphics from this course, I would recommend making this the prerequisite to the computer science major. Dr. Bennett's lectures are very thorough, and she gives THE BEST introduction to C programming at Yale (if you don't know, C is the primary language in the core courses of the computer science major). Dr. Bennett's introduction to C is even better than CS50 (I took both CS50 and ENAS 130) in my opinion because her lecture notes are really good and she provides so many sample codes that you can review and learn from. If you're deciding between CS50 and ENAS 130, I'd take CS50 if you want more breadth in your introduction to programming and ENAS 130 if you want more depth in your introduction to programming. I'd say the workload of CS50 is higher on average relative to ENAS 130, but at the end of the semester (last 2 or three weeks), the workload of ENAS 130 spikes and probably surpasses CS50. The connection with your instructor will definitely be better in ENAS 130, though, because Dr. Bennett actively reaches out to students, hosts frequent office hours, and is very friendly. Once again the introduction to C in ENAS 130 is unmatched and is better than any introductory course offered at Yale in this regard. I also haven't found many courses that use C++ as one of the primary languages, so if you want to get exposed to it, this course is a good option. I wasn't a fan of the computer graphics, but you have to recognize that this class is actually an introduction to computing for engineers, so it makes sense that computer graphics are covered. Also, it's still fun to apply your knowledge of the programming languages to the computer graphics problems and computer graphics concepts are not covered on the exams, so it's not too bad. My only warning to you if you're considering this class is that there are a good number of people that take this course that may have a stronger computing background than you and pretty much ruin the curve. I had been coding for a while before taking this class, so the problem sets were really not that much of a challenge, and the final problem set and project took me about one night, but I definitely think it would've taken me a lot longer had this been my first introductory computer science class (sorry fellow classmates). Also, elementary knowledge in linear algebra and multivariable calculus helped in the sense that I didn't really need to read some of the specifications for problem sets. What I'm saying is that Dr. Bennett is a great professor and you can definitely learn the concepts being taught, but your grade may be brought down by the fact that there are people with a lot more experience in the course who solve coding problems with ease. While this may be hypocritical since I took both CS50 and ENAS 130, I think that, in the future, you should not be able to take this class if you've already taken CS50 because the concepts are similar enough in the two courses that taking either class will be a review of what you've learned in the other, which gives you a noticeably unfair advantage to students that have no experience at all.
No, only take if required

I would recommend this course to a student who wants to learn new programming languages. It is a thorough introduction and so you could take it as a total beginner, but it will be easier if you have experience with object-oriented programming (eg. Java). You probably shouldn't take this course if you already know C or C++.
I would recommend this course for students looking to learn C and C++. Most of the matlab we learned was looking things up on the internet for specific use cases on the psets.
Yes, great comprehensive introduction to C and C++. Only touches a little on MATLAB.
I would recommend this course, but be prepared to put in the time at office hours, especially if you've never programmed before!
Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn coding skills that can be readily applicable in STEM fields.

Yes I would! I gained a lot of intuition on how to tackle problems with coding. It was challenging as a first time coder, but there's enough help and resources to get it done. You just have to put in the work. I might be easily amazed, but it was fun doing the psets with graphics. I felt those were especially rewarding.

I feel like this class could be easy for some and potentially the hardest class they have ever taken for others. If you already know about conditional statements and loops, you will enjoy this course.
Yes I would because it will challenge you and you must understand the content and learn how to code in C,C++ and Matlab in order to get a good grade

On the usefulness of skills provided, ask a CS major or an engineering grad student...I cannot say. 

On the quality of the class, yes absolutely.
I would recommend but this class requires much more time in the second half than the first.
Yes, especially if you are new to coding or if you decided to only do one coding class, I highly recommend  ENAS 130.
Yes, this course is super helpful if you go into any field/major that involves programming, and Professor Bennett is great.
Yes! This course is an amazing start to coding in the engineering field and will be crucial for any prospective engineer's time at yale.

Yes! Professor Bennett is great and she makes it so easy to learn in her classes. I personally really liked the material and how logical it felt. The workload is totally manageable as long as you start the psets early so that you can attend the less-crowded office hours. Be aware that the pset grading can feel harsh at times (i.e. getting a few points off for "little" things even when your code overall works) but overall (like for the final grades) the grading seems fair. Also, if you have any trouble in the course, reach out to Professor Bennett to let her know.
Yes, this course is a good introduction to programming.

Yes, this course was a fantastic programming course and Dr. Bennett is an amazing professor who really cares about her students and wants to see them succeed. As someone without much experience coming in, I attended many help sessions and office hours and really appreciate all the resources she has for students who need extra help. The course is time-consuming and requires a high level of effort, but it is time well-spent. This course is super rewarding and completing problem sets is very satisfying because you can clearly see yourself growing and learning and Dr. Bennett is very deliberate and intentional with her problem designs.
Yes, the work was manageable and all the resources are there for you to succeed.
I would definitely recommend this course to a student who wants to get their feet wet coding in C, C++, and matlab.
I would recommend this course for engineering students but not someone who just wants to learn how to code.
Yes! This is a great programming class for anyone with some experience programming or with none at all. Professor Bennett is amazing and makes the material so easy to learn.
For sure its very good and good for beginners and whatnot
I definitely recommend it! The class is extremely organized and very well-taught
Yes, absolutely!
Yes, great class.
This is a great introductory coding course and really gives you the resources and support to succeed.
Yes, it was a good course.
Yes!!!!
Yes, I would recommend because the professor was great. She really puts in effort to get to know and help each of her students individually.
ABSOLUTELY! Beth Anne Bennett is a gift.
Yes, take it because of Bennett
YES, great prof great subject great educational value
